node.title: A Top Official Says the Fed Will ‘Grapple’ With Faster Bond-Buying Taper
node.alt: John C. Williams, the president of Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
node.description: The president of the New York Federal Reserve said Omicron could prolong supply and demand mismatches, causing some inflation pressures to last.
node.content: ["John C. Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said the latest variant of the coronavirus could prolong the bottlenecks and shortages that have caused inflation to run hotter than expected, and is a risk Fed officials will assess as they \u201cgrapple\u201d with how quickly to remove economic support.", "It is still too soon to know how the Omicron variant, which public health officials in southern Africa identified just last week, will affect the economy, Mr. Williams said Tuesday in an interview with The New York Times. But if the new version of the virus leads to another wave of infections, it could exacerbate the disruptions that have caused prices to rise at their fastest pace in three decades.", "\u201cClearly, it adds a lot of uncertainty to the outlook,\u201d Mr. Williams said of the new variant. He later added that a risk with the new variant is that it \u201cwill continue that excess demand in the areas that don\u2019t have capacity, and will stall the recovery in the areas where we actually have the capacity.\u201d", "That, he said, would \u201cmean a somewhat slower rebound overall\u201d and \u201calso does increase those inflationary pressures, in those areas that are in high demand.\u201d", "Mr. Williams\u2019s comments are the latest indication that policymakers are growing more concerned about inflation and are weighing how to respond. Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, signaled on Tuesday that the central bank could move to withdraw economic support more quickly than it initially expected and suggested that such a decision could come as soon as the Fed\u2019s December meeting.", "The Fed had been buying $120 billion in government-backed securities each month throughout much of the pandemic to bolster the economy by keeping money flowing in financial markets. In November, officials announced plans to wind down that program gradually through the end of the year and the first half of 2022, a process known as \u201ctapering.\u201d But Mr. Powell indicated on Tuesday that the central bank could wrap up its bond-buying more quickly.", "Mr. Williams, who is vice chair of the Fed\u2019s policymaking Open Market Committee and is a top adviser to Mr. Powell, did not explicitly endorse a faster tapering process, saying that \u201cthere\u2019s a lot to learn and digest and think about coming up to the next meeting.\u201d", "But he emphasized that the economy had rebounded more strongly this year than he and other officials had been expecting, and said that the unemployment rate has fallen quickly. That economic strengthening at a moment of high inflation may warrant less Fed support, he said.", "\u201cThe question is: Would it make sense to end those purchases somewhat earlier, by maybe a few months, given how strong the economy is?\u201d he said. \u201cThat\u2019s a decision, discussion, I expect we\u2019ll have to grapple with.\u201d", "Inflation has proved a thornier problem than the Fed and most private-sector economists predicted earlier this year. In March, Fed officials said they expected their preferred inflation measure to show consumer prices rising at 2.4 percent at the end of 2021; by September, they had revised that forecast to 4.2 percent.", "That\u2019s likely to increase further. The central bank\u2019s preferred inflation gauge climbed 5 percent in its most recent reading. Policymakers are closely watching to see what happens in an upcoming Consumer Price Index report set for release on Dec. 10, just before the Fed\u2019s meeting on Dec. 14 and 15.", "Mr. Williams acknowledged that inflation had proven stronger and more lasting than he initially expected. But he said the error wasn\u2019t the result of a misunderstanding of how the economy works; rather, it was his failure to anticipate the resurgence of the pandemic itself. Mr. Powell made similar comments in his testimony before the Senate on Tuesday.", "The spread of the Delta variant over the summer delayed the return of workers to the labor force by disrupting child care and making some people nervous to return to in-person work. It also contributed to supply-chain issues by causing a new round of factory shutdowns in some parts of the world and by extending the pandemic-era shift in consumer spending away from services and toward goods.", "\u201cThese are all things that are driven \u2014 I think in large part, not totally, but in large part \u2014 to Covid, and the ability so far for us to get control of that,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is just lasting a lot longer than expected.\u201d", "The new variant, Mr. Williams added, \u201chas that potential to just extend this process we\u2019ve been going through.\u201d", "If the Omicron variant further delays the return of workers and the easing of supply shortages, that could lead to more and longer-lasting inflation. But a new wave of virus cases could also hurt the demand side of the economy, leading people to spend less at restaurants and movie theaters and provoking a new wave of layoffs.", "That scenario would put the Fed in a difficult position, forcing it to choose between withdrawing support for the economy in the face of rising unemployment and allowing inflation to accelerate unchecked.", "Mr. Powell has at times acknowledged that the two parts of the Fed\u2019s job \u2014 fostering maximum employment and maintaining stable prices \u2014 could be coming into tension. He nodded to the conflict again Tuesday, while emphasizing that controlling inflation is a critical goal.", "\u201cTo get back to the kind of great labor market we had before the pandemic, we\u2019re going to need a long expansion,\u201d Mr. Powell said. \u201cTo get that, we\u2019re going to need price stability.\u201d", "Mr. Williams said he was confident the Fed could chart a course that would allow the labor market to continue to improve while simultaneously reining in inflation.", "\u201cHow you deal with those trade-offs is something that we\u2019ve studied for a long time and we have experience with,\u201d he said. He added that he has seen little evidence so far that consumers and businesses have come to expect higher inflation to last long term \u2014 a chief worry for the Fed, because a lasting shift in expectations could make inflation harder for policymakers to control.", "\u201cIf inflation stays too high for too long, that will eventually seep into people\u2019s longer-term inflation expectations,\u201d he said.", "Fed officials should know more about the Omicron variant by the time they hold their meeting in mid-December. They will also have a better read on the state of the economy by then. On Friday, the Labor Department will release its monthly report on jobs and unemployment, and the update on inflation will also offer new evidence.", "But Mr. Williams said the longer-run effects of the pandemic are harder to gauge. The brief, pre-Delta surge in activity over the summer suggests that many Americans are eager to return to their old ways of in-person socializing, he said. But other shifts around work could prove more lasting, which could affect the economy in hard-to-predict ways.", "\u201cNow that we\u2019ve learned to live this way, are we going to go back to the old ways?\u201d he asked. \u201cI have to say, I don\u2019t know.\u201d"]
